title: About This Project
text: This website presents a comprehensive analysis of 42 bacterial isolates from the KPC-31 resistome project, focusing on carbapenemase-producing Klebsiella pneumoniae and Escherichia coli.

title: About This Project
text: This website presents a comprehensive analysis of 42 bacterial isolates from the KPC-31 resistome project, focusing on carbapenemase-producing Klebsiella pneumoniae and Escherichia coli.

title: About This Project
text:
Data Source
Dataset: Progetto 1 (KPC-31) versione 2.xlsx
The dataset includes: - 42 bacterial isolates - 155 variables covering: - Bacterial identification (species, MLST, capsular typing) - Antimicrobial susceptibility testing (MIC for ~26 antibiotics) - Resistance gene detection (36 genes) - Plasmid replicon typing (15 incompatibility groups)

title: About This Project
text:
Methodology

Bacterial Characterization

Species identification: Standard microbiological methods
Multi-locus sequence typing (MLST): Sequence type determination
Capsular typing (KL): K-locus characterization
Wzi typing: Capsule synthesis region analysis



Antimicrobial Susceptibility Testing
MIC (Minimum Inhibitory Concentration) values determined for approximately 26 antibiotics including: - Beta-lactams (including carbapenems) - Beta-lactam/beta-lactamase inhibitor combinations (CAZ-AVI, PIP-TAZ) - Aminoglycosides - Quinolones - Colistin
Resistance Interpretation: - CAZ-AVI Susceptible: MIC â‰¤8 mg/L - CAZ-AVI Intermediate: MIC 9-16 mg/L - CAZ-AVI Resistant: MIC >16 mg/L


Molecular Analysis

Resistance Gene Detection
36 resistance genes analyzed including: - Beta-lactamases: blaKPC-31, blaCTX-M-15, blaTEM, blaSHV variants, blaOXA - Aminoglycoside resistance: aac, aph, ant genes, armA (16S rRNA methylase) - Quinolone resistance: qnrB1, gyrA/ParC mutations - Other mechanisms: Sul1/Sul2 (sulfonamides), fosA (fosfomycin)


Plasmid Typing
15 incompatibility groups detected: - IncFIB(K), IncFII(K) - K. pneumoniae-specific IncF plasmids - IncX3 - Small mobilizable plasmid - IncR - Broad host range - IncN - Broad host range - Multiple other Inc groups



Data Analysis
All analyses performed using: - R version: 4.5.1 - Platform: Positron 2025.12.2 - Key packages: - tidyverse (v2.0.0) - data manipulation and visualization - readxl (v1.4.3) - Excel file import - ggplot2 (v4.0.1) - graphics - knitr and kableExtra - table formatting


Statistical Methods

Descriptive statistics (counts, percentages, medians)
Log2 transformation for MIC visualization
Hierarchical clustering for resistance patterns
Chi-square and Fisherâ€™s exact tests where appropriate

title: About This Project
text:
Limitations

Sample size: Limited to 42 isolates
Capsular typing: Only 23.8% (10/42) isolates have KL typing
Missing data: Variable completeness across different data types
Plasmid detection: 62% of isolates have no detectable Inc groups (possible chromosomal integration or novel plasmids)
Cross-sectional design: No temporal or longitudinal data available

title: About This Project
text:
Key Definitions

Molecular Typing

ST (Sequence Type): Classification based on multi-locus sequence typing (MLST) of housekeeping genes
KL (Capsular Type): Classification based on K-locus genetic structure
High-risk clone: Globally disseminated sequence types associated with multidrug resistance and virulence



Resistance Mechanisms

Carbapenemase: Enzyme that hydrolyzes carbapenem antibiotics (e.g., KPC-31)
ESBL: Extended-spectrum beta-lactamase (e.g., CTX-M-15)
16S rRNA methylase: Enzyme conferring pan-aminoglycoside resistance (e.g., armA)



Plasmid Biology

Inc group: Incompatibility group - plasmids classification based on replication systems
HGT: Horizontal gene transfer - movement of genetic material between bacteria
Conjugation: Transfer of plasmids between bacteria via cell-to-cell contact

title: About This Project
text:
Data Availability
The analysis code and this website are available on GitHub. The raw dataset is not publicly available due to potential patient privacy concerns.

title: About This Project
text:
Reproducibility
This analysis is fully reproducible. All code used to generate the figures and tables is embedded in the Quarto documents and can be viewed using the â€œCodeâ€ buttons throughout the report.

title: About This Project
text:
AI Assistance Disclosure






Note



This analysis was conducted with AI assistance (Databot in Positron) under human direction. All findings should be verified by qualified microbiologists and epidemiologists before clinical or public health decisions.

title: About This Project
text:
Technical Notes

Website Generation
This website was created using: - Quarto (v1.4+) - Scientific and technical publishing system - GitHub Pages - Free static website hosting - R Markdown - Dynamic document generation


Rendering
To regenerate this website locally:
# Install Quarto (https://quarto.org/docs/get-started/)

# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/YOUR-USERNAME/YOUR-REPO-NAME.git
cd YOUR-REPO-NAME

# Render the website
quarto render

# Preview locally
quarto preview


Software Versions

R: 4.5.1
Quarto: 1.4+
RStudio/Positron: 2025.12.2


Last updated: December 27, 2025

Option 2: Keep Data Private
1. Uncomment *.xlsx in .gitignore
2. git rm --cached "*.xlsx"
3. Users need local copy to run code
4. Website still shows all results (already rendered)

title: Comprehensive Resistome Analysis
text:
Note



This report was generated using AI under general human direction. At the time of generation, the contents have not been comprehensively reviewed by a human analyst.

title: Comprehensive Resistome Analysis
text:
Key Findings






ImportantCritical Discovery: Universal blaKPC-31 Carriage



ALL 42 isolates (100%) carry the blaKPC-31 carbapenemase gene, indicating this is a KPC-31-specific collection or outbreak. This variant is responsible for the observed carbapenem resistance and variable ceftazidime-avibactam (CAZ-AVI) resistance across isolates.



Dominant species: Klebsiella pneumoniae (78.6%, n=33)
Most prevalent sequence type: ST307 (50% of typed isolates, n=16)
High-risk clones identified: ST307, ST512, ST101, ST131, ST147
CAZ-AVI resistance: 35.7% show high-level resistance (MIC >16 mg/L)
Plasmid diversity: 15 incompatibility groups, with IncF plasmids spreading across multiple clones

==================


â€¢ Total isolates: 42

â€¢ Antibiotics tested (MIC): ~26


â€¢ Resistance genes analyzed: 36


â€¢ Plasmid Inc groups detected: 15

title: Comprehensive Resistome Analysis
text:
2.4 Capsular Types (KL)






ImportantPerfect KL-ST Association



Each capsular type is exclusively associated with one sequence type, suggesting stable clonal lineages:

KL107 â†”ï¸ ST512 (n=4)
KL102 â†”ï¸ ST307 (n=2)
KL17 â†”ï¸ ST101 (n=2)
KL64 â†”ï¸ ST147 (n=2)

Only 23.8% (10/42) of isolates have capsular typing data, but the perfect association is striking.

title: Comprehensive Resistome Analysis
text:

FigureÂ 4: Distribution of CAZ-AVI MIC values

title: Comprehensive Resistome Analysis
text:
3.2 CAZ-AVI Resistance by Sequence Type








FigureÂ 5: CAZ-AVI resistance stratified by sequence type











WarningST307 Heterogeneous Resistance



ST307 shows a 50/50 split between intermediate and resistant isolates, suggesting:

Evolving resistance mechanisms within this clone
Potential for further resistance development
Need for careful monitoring

title: Comprehensive Resistome Analysis
text:
3.3 Multi-Antibiotic Resistance Heatmap








FigureÂ 6: Median MIC values across antibiotics by sequence type

title: Comprehensive Resistome Analysis
text:
4.1 blaKPC-31: The Universal Carbapenemase








FigureÂ 7: blaKPC-31 prevalence across species and sequence types











ImportantUniversal KPC-31 Carriage



100% of isolates (42/42) carry blaKPC-31, including:

All K. pneumoniae isolates
All E. coli isolates (including lab strains)
All sequence types
Both clinical and environmental isolates

This indicates a KPC-31-specific collection or outbreak.

title: Comprehensive Resistome Analysis
text:

title: Comprehensive Resistome Analysis
text:
8.1 Treatment Challenges






WarningExtremely Limited Treatment Options



All isolates carry blaKPC-31, resulting in:

âœ— Carbapenems: Compromised by carbapenemase
âš ï¸ CAZ-AVI: Variable resistance (35.7% high-level)
âš ï¸ Aminoglycosides: Compromised (especially ST101 with armA)
âš ï¸ Quinolones: Resistance common (gyrA, ParC, qnrB1)




8.1.1 Potential Treatment Strategies

title: Comprehensive Resistome Analysis
text:
8.2 Infection Control Priorities

8.2.1 High-Risk Clones for Isolation

ST512 (KL107): IncX3 plasmid stable but high resistance
ST101 (KL17): armA-mediated pan-aminoglycoside resistance
ST147 (KL64): IncF plasmids with high HGT potential



8.2.2 Surveillance Recommendations





Priority
Target
Rationale




Critical
IncF plasmid spread
Spreading across 4 STs, HGT evidence


Critical
blaKPC-31 variants
Monitor for evolution (KPC-32, KPC-33, etc.)


High
ST307 mechanism
No Inc groups detected - chromosomal integration?


High
Capsular typing
Strong predictor of resistance phenotype


Moderate
CAZ-AVI MICs
Early detection of resistance evolution

title: Comprehensive Resistome Analysis
text:
9.1 Key Findings Summary

Universal blaKPC-31 carriage (100%, 42/42) defines this collection
ST307 is dominant (50% of typed isolates) but shows heterogeneous resistance
Perfect KL-ST associations indicate stable clonal lineages
IncF plasmids are disseminating across multiple K. pneumoniae clones
Clone-specific resistance mechanisms:

ST512: IncX3-based (stable, not spreading)
ST101: IncR-based (armA-mediated pan-AMG resistance)
ST147: IncF-based (high HGT risk)
ST307: Unknown mechanism (requires investigation)

title: Comprehensive Resistome Analysis
text:
9.2 Critical Questions for Further Investigation






TipRecommended Next Steps




Whole plasmid sequencing: Map complete genetic context of resistance genes
ST307 mechanism: Investigate chromosomal vs cryptic plasmid integration
IncX3 plasmid characterization: Complete sequence of ST512 blaKPC-31-bearing plasmid
Temporal analysis: If collection dates available, track resistance evolution
Epidemiological links: Investigate patient/ward connections for transmission chains
Functional studies: Test plasmid transferability and fitness costs

title: Comprehensive Resistome Analysis
text:
9.3 Public Health Implications






ImportantOutbreak Potential



This collection represents either:

A KPC-31-specific outbreak with multiple introductions
A surveillance collection of endemic KPC-31 strains
Clonal expansion of resistant lineages with horizontal gene transfer

The presence of high-risk global clones (ST307, ST512, ST101, ST131, ST147) combined with active plasmid dissemination (IncF family) represents a significant public health concern requiring immediate infection control measures.

title: Comprehensive Resistome Analysis
text:
10.1 Data Source

Dataset: Progetto 1 (KPC-31) versione 2.xlsx
42 bacterial isolates
155 variables including:

Bacterial identification (species, MLST, capsular typing)
Antimicrobial susceptibility testing (MIC for ~26 antibiotics)
Resistance gene detection (36 genes)
Plasmid replicon typing (15 incompatibility groups)

title: Comprehensive Resistome Analysis
text:
10.2 Analytical Approach
All analyses were performed using R version 4.5.1 with the following packages:

tidyverse for data manipulation and visualization
readxl for Excel file import
ggplot2 for graphics
knitr and kableExtra for tables


10.2.1 Resistance Categorization

CAZ-AVI Susceptible: MIC â‰¤8 mg/L
CAZ-AVI Intermediate: MIC 9-16 mg/L
CAZ-AVI Resistant: MIC >16 mg/L



10.2.2 Statistical Notes

Percentages calculated on non-missing values
Median MIC used for heatmaps to reduce outlier effects
Log2 transformation applied for MIC visualization

title: KPC-31 Resistome Analysis Project
text:
This website presents a comprehensive genomic and phenotypic analysis of 42 bacterial isolates from the KPC-31 resistome project. The collection includes carbapenemase-producing Klebsiella pneumoniae and Escherichia coli isolates with detailed molecular characterization.






ImportantCritical Finding



ALL 42 isolates (100%) carry the blaKPC-31 carbapenemase gene, making this a KPC-31-specific collection with significant clinical and epidemiological implications.

title: KPC-31 Resistome Analysis Project
text:
This website presents a comprehensive genomic and phenotypic analysis of 42 bacterial isolates from the KPC-31 resistome project. The collection includes carbapenemase-producing Klebsiella pneumoniae and Escherichia coli isolates with detailed molecular characterization.






ImportantCritical Finding



ALL 42 isolates (100%) carry the blaKPC-31 carbapenemase gene, making this a KPC-31-specific collection with significant clinical and epidemiological implications.

title: KPC-31 Resistome Analysis Project
text:
Quick Summary



Dataset Overview

42 bacterial isolates
155 variables analyzed
26 antibiotics tested
36 resistance genes detected
15 plasmid Inc groups identified




Key Findings

78.6% K. pneumoniae
ST307 most prevalent (50%)
100% blaKPC-31 positive
High CAZ-AVI resistance (35.7%)
Active plasmid dissemination

title: KPC-31 Resistome Analysis Project
text:
Analysis Sections

Full Report
Access the complete analysis including:

Bacterial Characterization: Species distribution, sequence types (ST), capsular types (KL)
Resistance Phenotypes: MIC distributions for 26 antibiotics, resistance patterns by clone
Resistance Genotypes: Comprehensive gene profiling, blaKPC-31 analysis
Plasmid Analysis: Incompatibility groups, horizontal gene transfer evidence
Clinical Implications: Treatment recommendations, infection control priorities

title: KPC-31 Resistome Analysis Project
text:
Highlights

Species DistributionHigh-Risk ClonesPlasmid FindingsClinical Impact


Klebsiella pneumoniae dominates the collection (78.6%, n=33), with E. coli variants comprising 21.4%.


Five high-risk sequence types identified: - ST307 (n=16): Global high-risk clone with heterogeneous resistance - ST512 (n=5): IncX3 plasmid-associated, 100% CAZ-AVI resistant - ST101 (n=7): armA-mediated pan-aminoglycoside resistance - ST147 (n=2): IncF plasmids with high HGT potential - ST131 (n=2): E. coli pandemic clone



IncF plasmids spreading across 4 different sequence types
IncX3 fixed in ST512 (100% prevalence)
62% of isolates have no detectable Inc groups (chromosomal integration?)



Limited treatment options due to: - Universal blaKPC-31 carriage - Variable CAZ-AVI resistance (35.7% high-level) - Multiple resistance mechanisms per isolate - Active horizontal gene transfer

title: KPC-31 Resistome Analysis Project
text:
Key Visualizations
The full report contains interactive visualizations showing:

Species and sequence type distributions
CAZ-AVI resistance patterns by clone
Multi-antibiotic resistance heatmaps
Resistance gene profiles
Plasmid incompatibility group networks
Integrated analysis of plasmids, genes, and phenotypes

title: KPC-31 Resistome Analysis Project
text:
Study Significance
This analysis reveals:

Universal blaKPC-31 dissemination across multiple high-risk clones
Perfect KL-ST associations indicating stable clonal lineages
Clone-specific resistance mechanisms (plasmid-based vs chromosomal)
Active horizontal gene transfer of IncF plasmids within K. pneumoniae
Urgent need for infection control measures







WarningPublic Health Concern



The combination of high-risk global clones (ST307, ST512, ST101, ST131, ST147) with active plasmid dissemination represents a significant public health threat requiring immediate intervention.
